body: $IONQ I highly recommend people read the Scorpion short report. Don't let bulls here convince you that the report is BS without looking into it yourself and coming to your own conclusion. Most people here have large positions and are very biased in their perspective. I don't care which way this stock goes as I exited my position a long time ago during the initial pump. But I caution the blind optimism / bullishness on this page. These guys have a good track record of shorting stocks that end up dumping significantly over time. Do your own due diligence

body: Error rate and gate fidelity are on the opposite ends of the same coin.
IonQ has an infographic stating >98% on Two-qubit gates.  This is does not mean 2% error; you don't simply subtract the fidelity from 100 to get the error.

body: $IONQ: SHAREHOLDER ALERT: Pomerantz Law Firm Investigates Claims On Behalf of Investors of IonQ
Quantum computing is based on probabilities.  When an algorithm is used
created_at: an output is generated based on the states of the qubits.  This output may or may not be correct due to measurement errors
column4: and environmental interference.  Measuring a qubit is not 100% accurate.

created_at: running an algorithm for 1+1 may generate different answers (as seen in the short report).  But the key here is looking at the probabilities and the **expectation value**.  If you're able to generate the correct answer 2/3 of the time
column3: it's considered solid in quantum computing.

body: This is pretty much spot on with the short report (66% rounded from 65.6%).  Their shot count is 1000 with 4 mutually exclusive experiments.  And they generated the correct answer 2/3 of the time across the aggregated data.  Now
column3: the problem can be with the algorithm
column4: not the machine.  The 1000 shot count may also not be sufficient for appropriate probability distributions.
